ext_descriptions:
This type identifies the types of entity which may be selected as the underlying geometry of a .
This type identifies the types of entity which may be selected as the underlying geometry of a .
This select type identifies the types of entities in a geometric model which can be linked to a .
This select type identifies the types of entities that are used as items in the definition of a .
A Complex_triangulated_face is a type of
defining the geometry as a set of triangles arranged in strips and fans.
The ordering of the points used to define the strips or fans of triangles is shown in Figure 1.
Ordering of points for Complex_triangulated_face
the list of integers defining the locations in the
list of the points and normals of the triangles.
the list of lists of INTEGERs giving the locations of the coordinate values in the
list for each strip of triangles. Each sublist defines the orders in the
list, via the pnindex if used, of the vertices of the ith strip of triangles.
If required a single triangle can be included in this structure as a strip of one triangle, in which case the sublist will contain 3 INTEGERs.
the list of lists of INTEGERs giving the locations of the coordinate values in the
list for each fan of triangles. Each sublist defines the orders in the
list of the vertices of the ith fan of triangles.
In the simplest case where no point is associated with more than 1 normal and the size of
is
the triangles defined by the strips and fans refer directly to the
list and pnindex is empty. In all other cases pnindex is required to identify points and normals for the triangles.
The size of pnindex, if non-zero, shall be equal to .
The pnindex shall not be empty unless
is equal to the size of the
list.
This option can only be used in the simple case of a local
and 0 or 1 normals per point.
The triangle_strips list and the triangle_fans list shall not both be empty.
A Complex_triangulated_surface_set is a type of
defining the geometry by a set of triangles arranged in strips and fans.
The ordering of the points used to define the strips or fans of triangles is shown in Figure 1.
the list of integers defining the locations in the
list of the points and normals of the triangles.
the list of lists of INTEGERs giving the locations of the coordinate values in the
list for each strip of triangles. Each sublist defines the orders in the
list, via the pnindex if used, of the vertices of the ith strip of triangles.
If required a single triangle can be included in this structure as a strip of one triangle, in which case the sublist will contain 3 INTEGERs.
the list of lists of INTEGERs giving the locations of the coordinate values in the
list for each fan of triangles. Each sublist defines the orders in the
list of the vertices of the ith fan of triangles.
In the simplest case where no point is associated with more than 1 normal and the size of
is
the triangles defined by the strips and fans refer directly to the
list and pnindex is empty.
The size of pnindex, if non-zero, shall be equal to .
The pnindex shall not be empty unless
is equal to the size of the
list.
This option can only be used in the simple case of a local
and 0 or 1 normals per point.
The triangle_strips list and the triangle_fans list shall not both be empty.
A Coordinates_list is a type of
that defines the coordinate values for points used in a .
the number of points with coordinates in the list.
the list of real triples defining the coordinates of the points.
These real triples have the semantics of length measures, but are not formally defined as such, the units for these are defined since a
is required to be used in a
having a .
The value of npoints shall be equal to the size of the position_coords list.
This entity shall not be instantiated as a complex subtype with .
This rule together with the ONEOF rule on the supertype
ensures that it is not instantiated with any subtype of .
A Repositioned_tessellated_item is a type of
which has been re-postioned by defining the coordinates with respect to a new axis system.
an
defining the origin and axis direction for the coordinates of the referenced points in the Repositioned_tessellated_item.
A Repositioned_tessellated_item shall only be used as a complex subtype with one of the following types of : a , a , a , a , a , a , or a .
A Tessellated_annotation is a type of
where the annotation geometry is provided as an .
the
that is styled by the Tessellated_annotation.
A Tessellated_connecting_edge is a type of . The Tessellated_connecting_edge connects two faces and contains information relating to the face normals.
a LOGICAL variable; if TRUE, there is tangent continuity where two faces join along this edge.
the first
using this edge.
the second
using this edge.
the list of integers giving the locations in the normals list of face1 of the normals on the face1 side at consecutive points of this edge, and, for connection checking, if required, the locations in the face1 coordinates list or face1 pnindex of consecutive points of this edge; in cases where normals are not defined for face1 the locations in the coordinates list are given;
the list of integers giving the locations in the normals list of face2 of the normals on the face2 side at consecutive points of this edge, and, for connection checking, if required, the locations in the face2 coordinates list or face2 pnindex of consecutive points of this edge; in cases where normals are not defined for face2 the locations in the coordinates list are given.
The line_strip_face1 and line_strip_face2 shall be of the same size.
The line_strip_face1 shall be of the same size as the inherited
attribute.
face1 shall not be of type .
face2 shall not be of type .
A Cubic_bezier_tessellated_edge is a type of which takes the form of a piecewise cubic bezier curve. The Cubic_bezier_tessellated_edge has its geometry defined by a list of control points, referenced by the inherited attribute; in this list only the points corresponding to ends of segments lie on the edge and the list of pointers is of length 3n +1, where n is the number of segments.
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ Schema: Tessellated_geometry_arm Entity: Cubic_bezier_tessellated_edge Attribute: line_strip
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
the list of 3n + 1 integers, where n is the number of cubic segments, giving the locations in the list of consecutive control points points of this edge.
A Cubic_tessellated_connecting_edge is a type of which takes the form of a cubic curve and connects 2 s. The Cubic_tessellated_connecting_edge has its geometry defined by a list of control points contained in the inherited attribute; in this list only the points corresponding to vertices of the cubic triangles of the adjacent faces lie on the edge and the list of pointers is of length 3n +1, where n is the number of triangles with adjacent edges on each side of the connecting edge.
a LOGICAL variable; if TRUE, there is tangent continuity where two faces join along this edge.
the to the left of this edge.
the to the right of this edge.
A Tessellated_curve_set is a type of
that is a tessellated representation of a collection of curves. The geometry of each curve is defined as a list of points obtained via the line_strips attribute.
the
giving the coordinate values for points of the curves.
the list of lists of integers defining the locations in the coordinates list of the consecutive points for each curve.
A Tessellated_edge is a type of . The geometry of the Tessellated_edge is approximated by straight line segments joining the points listed.
A Tessellated_edge may be used as the boundary between two Tessellated_faces.
the
giving the coordinate values for points of the Tessellated_edge.
the
of an exact model to which this Tessellated_edge corresponds. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the list of integers giving the locations in the coordinates list of consecutive points of this edge.
A Tessellated_face is a type of
that represents a face of a tessellated model. A Tessellated_face is either a
or a .
the
for the points of the face.
the larger of the number of points defined with the face or the number of unique point and normal combinations in the face.
the list of REAL triples defining the normals at the points of the face. If the size of this list is greater than one the ordering of the normals is the same as the ordering used for the points via pnindex in one of the subtypes.
the face or surface of an exact model to which this Tessellated_face corresponds. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
The size of normals shall be 0, 1 or equal to pnmax.
If size = 0 normals are undefined at all face points, if size = 1 the normal has the same value at each face point and the underlying surface is planar, if size is greater than 1 each point on the face has an individual underlying surface normal defined.
A Tessellated_geometric_set is a type of
that is a collection of Tessellated_items.
the individual items of tessellated geometry.
A Tessellated_item is a type of
used in the description of a tessellated shape. A Tessellated_item is either a , a , a , a , a , a , a , a , or a .
A Tessellated_item shall only be used in a .
A Tessellated_point_set is a type of
that is a collection of points used to define tessellated geometry.
the
giving the coordinate values for points of the set.
the list of locations in the coordinates list of the individual points of this set.
A Tessellated_shape_representation is a type of
in which the geometry is approximately represented by a tessellated model with planar facets.
The context of the Tessellated_shape_representation shall be a . This ensures that the coordinates used to define the points of the tessellated geometry have defined units.
The Tessellated_shape_representation shall shall contain at least 1 in the set.
A Tessellated_shell is a type of
that is a tessellated representation of a shell. Its geometry is defined as a set of Tessellated_structured_items.
The Tessellated_structured_items defining the geometry may be relocated in a local coordinate system by defining a complex instance of this entity with a .
the set of Tessellated_structured_items defining the faces of the shell.
a
representing the exact geometry of the shell. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
A Tessellated_solid is a type of
that is a tessellated representation of a solid model. Its geometry is defined as a set of Tessellated_structured_items.
The Tessellated_structured_items defining the geometry may be relocated in a local coordinate system by defining a complex instance of this entity with a .
the set of Tessellated_structured_items defining the faces of the solid.
a corresponding exact model of the solid. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
A Tessellated_structured_item is a type of
which has a topological structure. The links to topological components of an exact geometric model are defined with the subtypes. A Tessellated_structured_item may be either a , a , or a .
A Tessellated_surface_set is a type of
that is a tessellated representation of a collection of surfaces.
If the surfaces are triangulated the geometry of the surfaces is fully defined by creating an instance of one of the subtypes.
A Tessellated_surface_set is either a
or a .
the
for the vertices of the triangles.
the larger of the number of points defined with the triangles or the number of unique point and normal combinations in the set of triangles.
In the case of a Tessellated_surface_set with a discontinuous boundary between faces it is possible to have more than one normal defined at a point on the boundary.
the list of REAL triples defining the normals at the vertices of the triangles. If the size of this list is greater than one the ordering of the normals is the same as the ordering used for the pnindex.
The size of normals shall be 0, 1 or equal to pnmax.
If size = 0 normals are undefined at all vertices, if size = 1 the normal has the same value at each vertex and the underlying surface is planar, if size is greater than 1 each triangle vertex has an individual underlying surface normal defined.
A Tessellated_vertex is a type of
and is a single vertex in a tessellated model.
the
giving the vertex coordinate values.
an optional link to a topological
entity. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the location in the coordinates list of the coordinates for this vertex.
A Tessellated_wire is a type of
that is a tessellated representation of a collection of bounded curves joined end to end. Its geometry is defined as a set of tessellated edges and vertices.
The edges and vertices defining the geometry may be relocated in a local coordinate system by defining a complex instance of this entity with a .
the set of tessellated_edge_or_vertexs defining the geometry of the wire.
the corresponding exact geometry which may be a . The value of this attribute need not be specified.
A Triangulated_face is a type of
that has its geometry defined by a set of triangles.
the list of integers defining the locations in the
list of the points and normals of the triangles of the face.
the list of INTEGER triples, in the range 1 to , giving the locations of the coordinate values in the
list or in pnindex for each triangle. The ith triple in the list defines the orders in the appropriate list of the 3 vertices of the ith triangle.
See Figure 2 for further details of use of pnindex.
Use of pnindex to locate coordinates
In the simplest case where no point is associated with more than 1 normal and the size of
is
the triangles refer directly to the
list and pnindex is empty. In all other cases pnindex is required to identify points and normals for the triangles.
The size of pnindex, if non-zero, shall be equal to .
The pnindex shall not be empty unless
is equal to the size of the
list.
This option can only be used in the simple case of a local
and 0 or 1 normals per point.
A Cubic_bezier_triangulated_face is a type of that has its geometry defined by a set of curved triangles. Each of the triangles is a 3 sided Bezier cubic surface defined by a list of 10 control points, 9 near the edges and one above the centre. The control points P1 , P2 , P3 , are at the vertices of the triangle. Each triangle is a bi-parametric surface with equation: s(u,v) = (1 - u -v)3P1 + u3P2 + v3P3 + 3(1 - u -v)2uP4 + 3(1 - u -v)u2P5 + 3u2vP6 + 3uv2P7 + 3(1 - u -v)v2P8 + 3(1 - u -v)2vP9 + 6uv(1 - u -v)P10
The parametric range for each triangle is 0 ≤ u ≤ 1; 0 ≤ v ≤ 1; with u + v ≤ 1.
At each vertex the tangent along the edge of the triangle is in the direction of the next conrol point along this edge and has a magnnitude equal to 3 times this distance. At vertex P1 the tangent vector along the edge u = 0 is t = 3(P4 -P1), other tangent vectors are defined in a similar way.
Continuity of geometry between adjacent triangles is assured provided the adjacent edges reference the same 4 control points. Each edge of the triangle is a Bezier cubic curve of parametric length 1 defined by the 4 control points along that edge. P1, P4, P5, P2 define the cubic curve of the first edge of the triangle, other edges are defined in a similar manner.
Relationship between control points and triangular surface
See Figure (3) for illustration of the numbering of the control points.
the list of list of 10 INTEGER pointers, giving the locations of the coordinate values of the control points for each triangle in the list. The control points for each triangle are ordered as shown in Figure (3)
The size of list. shall be zero, the geometry of each triangle is completely defined by the control points.
A Triangulated_surface_set is a type of
defining the geometry of the surface set as a set of triangles. The individual triangles are defined by listing the coordinates of their vertices. Normals to the surfaces defined by the set of triangles may be included.
the list of integers defining the locations in the coordinates list of the points and normals of the triangles.
See Figure 2 for further details of use of pnindex.
the list of INTEGER triples, in the range 1 to pnmax, giving the locations of the coordinate values in the
list or pnindex for each triangle. The ith triple in the list defines the orders in the appropriate list of the 3 vertices of the ith triangle.
In the simplest case where no point is associated with more than 1 normal and the size of
is
the triangles refer directly to the
list and pnindex is empty.
The size of pnindex, if non-zero, shall be equal to .
The pnindex shall not be empty unless
is equal to the size of the
list.
This option can only be used in the simple case of a local
and 0 or 1 normals per point.
